awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Novel Computational Models and Algorithms for Mapping Link-Read Sequencing Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Innovative low-cost and low-input DNA library preparation techniques, using microfluidic molecular barcoding, have been developed. These technologies, also known as Linked-Read sequencing, offer additional long-range information over standard short-reads that are present on the same DNA molecule. The limited number of available tools do not meet the fast-growing needs of the community, because they focus on simple applications, lack the desired sensitivity, and are computationally expensive. This project will develop sensitive algorithms for mapping Linked-Reads to the reference genome. The method has also potential in solving other challenging problems such as the accurate discovery and assembly of structural variants and resolving repeat regions in the genome.

While there are an enormous amount of computational methods using standard short-read sequencing technologies, there is yet no comprehensive set of scalable algorithms that can be applied effectively to Linked-Read sequencing technologies. This project will develop novel probabilistic models and algorithms to address several computationally challenging problems, leveraging Linked-Read sequencing technologies. In particular, the project will develop a novel probabilistic framework and a sensitive algorithm for mapping Linked-Reads to the reference genome with applications to sensitive structural variation detection. Successful completion of this project will provide fast and scalable computational methods that can be applied to large-scale whole-genome data. The planned methods, tools and related test data sets will be made freely available online with extensive documentation on GitHub for the community to use and benefit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the life of the award (2018-2021), the PI completed several projects, published high impact-papers, graduated two Ph.D. students and established broader impacts.

The project was initiated to study linked-read sequencing techniology and dataset and developing mapping algorithms enabling downstream analysis for linked-read data.

The first main outcome of this project was a graph-based mapping-free algorithm to deconvole linke-read data. This project was in collaboraton with co-PI Mason (led by Ph.D. David Danko co-supervised by the PI and co-PI). This work was published in the journal Genome Research in 2019 (already cited 25 times, google scholar) and was highlighted in the RECOMB 2019 conference.  In this paper, we formally described a particular algorithmic issue common to linked-read technology: the deconvolution of reads with a single 3′ barcode into clusters that represent single long fragments of DNA. We introduced Minerva, a graph-based algorithm that approximately solves the barcode deconvolution problem for metagenomic data (where reference genomes may be incomplete or unavailable). Additionally, we developed two demonstrations where the deconvolution of barcoded reads improves downstream results. Our publications, source code and software are all are open access and open source. 

The second main outcome of this grant was a novel algorithm for mapping large-scale structural variants using linked-read data. We published this work in the journal Genome Biology in 2020. 

 We also gave an oral presentation on the early development of this work at the ISMB 2019 meeting. As part of this work, we developed novel algorithms to characterize large interspersed segmental duplications, inversions, deletions, and translocations in human genomes using linked-read sequencing data. Again our publications, source code and software are all are open access and open source. The Genome Biology journal invited me to write a report on the AGBT 2019 meeting mostly about sequencing technologies (including linked-read) which I published in the journal separetely as well. 

The third main outcome of this grant was a linked-read method for detection and assembly of novel sequence insertions, DNA sequences present in a given sequenced sample but missing in the reference genome, without requiring whole genome de novo assembly. In this paper, we proposed a novel integrated alignment-based and local-assembly-based algorithm, Novel-X, that effectively uses the barcode information encoded in linked-read sequencing datasets to improve detection of such events without the need of whole genome de novo assembly. This work (led by my Ph.D. student) was also presented at the ISMB meeting and the journal version is under review.  The source code and software is open source and available on GitHub and we deposited a preprint in bioRxiv.

With the start of the covid-19 pandemic, my co-PI Dr. Mason led a big effort in characterizing and profiling patients and their molecular tests from our affiliated hospitals. As a side project, I also contributed to the effort and published a paper in Nature Communications with them. I also contributed to a novel method for the assembly of the SARS-COV-2 viral RNA (led by my Ph.D. student) which we published at the journal Bioinformatics.

This grant partially supported several other project in my lab which I listed in the publication produced as a result of this research section.
